T he R eassurance of D ietetics foods means nothing, either legally or scientifically; it is simply designed to be reassuring. The science of nutrition did not get much attention from either scientists or the general public until the beginning of the twentieth century. The attitude of the med- ical profession was one of mild and amused good-will. Even before the nineteenth century there had been research into the criteria deter- mining life. Scientists attempted to explain the difference between inert matter and living matter, and gradually worked out the chemical composition of organic and mineral substances. It was discovered that proteins, glucids and lipids are ‘alimen- tary principles’, foods able to give us the physical and mental energy we need in order to live. The essential part played by proteins in the formation and renewal of organic tissue was established. The first scientific studies of nutrition, incidentally, were almost entirely from the physiological viewpoint. It was not until the end of the century – in France, perhaps as a result of the famine during the siege of Paris in 1870 –1 – that anyone took the importance of nutrition to health seriously, or understood that inadequate diet plays a part in causing disease. Art and literature had drawn new inspiration from medieval and Gothic sources, but no one thought anything of ancient medicine, thereby dismissing the only part of it which really was still of value, its dietetics. It was in the nineteenth century that people tried calculating human require- ments in terms of calories. What exactly is a calorie? In 1842 the German physician Julius Robert von Mayer (1814 –78) set out to determine the mechanical equivalent of heat by calculating the amount of heat produced by the compression of gases. He was the first to formulate the principle of the conservation of energy, in the same way as Lavoisier had demonstrated the conservation of matter. His work was con- tinued by such scientists as Joule, Helmotz, Sadi Carnot, and Clapeyron. Liebig divided foods into two categories: nitrogenous substances, those ‘plastic foods’ he thought necessary to replace muscular tissue worn down by work; and non-nitrogenous substances, those ‘respiratory foods’ (carbohydrates and fats) which were turned into heat by oxidation. Following on from his work and that of Marcellin Berthelot (1827–1907), scientists discovered that ingested substances gave off heat progressively within the organism. A quantitative appraisal of the calorific value of foods could now be made. Metabolism means the process whereby food is broken down and transformed within the organism into nutriments or simple elements which the cells can assimilate directly. It is accompanied, therefore, by liberation of the energy necessary to the automatic functioning of our bodies: the heartbeat, respiration, circulation of the blood, con- tractions of the stomach, peristaltic movements of the intestines, cell renewal and muscle tone. This basic metabolism (worked out on a basis of calories per square metre of cutaneous body surface per hour) varies with age, sex, climate, occupation, health and hormonal balance, including the effects of the functioning of the thyroid gland. A calorie is the amount of heat necessary to raise the temperature of a kilo of water one degree centigrade at normal atmospheric pressure. One gram of glucids ingested liberates four calories; one gram of lipids nine calories; one gram of protids four calories. Thus a food provides more or less energy according to its richness in 681 9781405181198_4_026.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 681

S cience and C onscience in the D iet glucids, protids or lipids. Calories are usually worked out per 100 grams of food- stuffs to facilitate calculation. Enzymes, or diastases, also enter into the process of metabolism. Enzymes are natural catalysts secreted by certain cells of the organism such as the salivary glands, and they are also found in a natural state in foods of animal and vegetable origin. The papaya, for instance, contains an enzyme which will pre-digest raw meat. The Africans, who have to eat meat directly it is slaughtered because of the risk of rapid putrefaction in a hot climate, wrap it in papaya leaves before they cook it. Such extremely fresh meat would normally be very tough, but wrapped in the leaves it is as tender and succulent as if it had been hung to perfection. Papain, the juice of the fruit or the leaves, is also used for gastric disorders. The mere presence of these enzymes makes them active in the breaking down of food and its assimilation in the diges- tive and cellular systems. Providing energy, however, is not the only purpose of food. Early twentieth- century laboratory experiments, particularly those of T. B. Osborne and C. B. Mendel in 1909 in the United States, demonstrated that life – even in small forms of animal life – could not be maintained if the experimental subjects were given not food but only nutrients in a chemically pure state: proteins, lipids, glucids and mineral salts. Purification, like sterilization, destroys what might be described as the life principle. Even earlier, in Java in 1901, a Dutch doctor called Ejkmann who kept chickens happened to notice some of them showing the fatal symptoms of polyneuritis seen in beri-beri, a deficiency disease found among peoples who eat only polished rice. He realized what the cause of the symptoms was, and cured his chickens by adding rice bran to their feed. What had been considered an impurity, therefore, contained a substance necessary to life. Our ancestors, who lived mainly on coarsely bolted cereals (wheat, maize and rice), had been right, although as they had no choice in the matter perhaps they did not know it. In 1914 the Polish doctor C. Fink proved that the substance of life existed in cereal husks, although he was unable to isolate it chemically. Because of the chem- ically carbonaceous nature of bran, amine (which in fact has nothing to do with it), he suggested the name of vitamin . Worldwide scientific study of the subject was unable to continue until after the end of the First World War. From 1920 onwards, work on the identification, isola- tion and synthesization of vitamins was a major part of nutritional physiology and biochemistry, particularly as a result of the studies of the Swiss scientist P. Karrer. However, vitamin or protein deficiencies are not the only causes of deficiency diseases which may attack whole populations, particularly in the Third World. Between the wars people learned to recognize and combat certain diseases caused by a deficiency of inorganic nutrients: endemic goitre and anaemia, to name but two, associated respectively with iodine and iron deficiency. In modern times intensive research on deficiency diseases has extended to other fields. Besides its increasing influence on medicine, hygiene, the economy and the social sciences (through better understanding of public health), the science of nutrition has become important in the breeding technology of agriculture, and most of all in the food industry, upon which the question of hunger in tomorrow’s world largely depends. 682 9781405181198_4_026.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 682

T he R eassurance of D ietetics Vitamins Vitamins are organic substances indispensable to the functioning and regulation of the organism. The body cannot manufacture them, and has to find them in food or synthesize them from certain foods (in the case, for instance, of vitamin A or retinol). Only very small doses are required, of the order of a milligram. The same vitamin may occur in a number of foods, and the improvement in living conditions since the Second World War has caused such major deficiency diseases as scurvy and beri-beri to disappear from industrialized countries. However, alcoholism, nicotine poisoning, peculiar diets undertaken without med- ical supervision, anorexia in old age and serious diseases all cause deficiencies that only a doctor can correct, after analysis or examination of the patient. The fashion for vitamin pills simply makes money for the laboratories that manufacture them. In cases of hypervitaminosis, the organism can usually eliminate the excess easily enough, but too much vitamin A may cause hypertension and too much vitamin D upsets the metabolism. A balanced diet guarantees the necessary quantities of vitamins, although it should be remembered that vitamins are altered or destroyed by prolonged storage and by cooking, particularly the very perishable vitamin C. Twenty per cent of vitamin B1 is lost in cooking, but vitamin B2 is not affected. Vitamins are classified as hydrosoluble (soluble in water) or liposoluble (soluble in fatty matter). The former are therefore impaired by boiling in water, in which they will dissolve, and the latter by cooking in fat. 683 9781405181198_4_026.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 683

690 27 AR eassuring F uture S ince the year 2000 the population of our planet has swiftly risen above six and a half million, and all those people have to be fed. Meanwhile, the nutritional and agricultural industries of the world are working to dominate rather than be dom- inated by technology in order to achieve their prime aim. In the industrialized coun- tries the agro-nutritional industries as a whole, which may be described in general terms as the food-processing industry, have to ensure that the dietary needs of human- ity are met in line with two imperatives. They must work: • to maintain human health by the provision of basic foodstuffs, meaning healthy, everyday food of good nutritional quality; • to contribute to the quality of life by providing food for what might be called leisure consumption (for instance on special or festive occasions), meaning food- stuffs of particularly high quality and with aesthetic appeal to the senses. While the year 2000 still seemed as distant as a mirage, science-fiction authors used to give free rein to their surrealistic imagination, holding out the prospect of programmed diets based on pills and nutritional concentrates, a vision to make Brillat- Savarin turn in his grave. Then the date came so close that in the end we finally accepted it as reality; we were forced to realize that the tomorrow of the millennium was not so mythical after all, and indeed was already with us. The nutritional pill is still in the futuristic realm of fiction, although protein and vitamin concentrates are therapeutically used in certain specific cases. Researchers all over the planet are proving both realistic and ingenious. If we must eat to live, then naturally the pleasure of eating must also be preserved; it is more than the beginning of happiness. First comes a certain sense of well-being, both phys- ical (of course) and psychological. In general, that is a sign of good health. Today, no one can ignore the fact that our health depends on what we eat. All scientific studies confirm that fact. It is true that illnesses which are not caused by microbes, those we describe as the diseases of civilization, such as cancer, cardiovascular disorders, osteoporosis, diabetes, 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 690 A History of Food Maguelonne Toussaint-Samat © 2009 Blackwell Publishing Ltd. AR eassuring F uture obesity and hypercholesterolaemia (high blood cholesterol), do not depend entirely on our diet, but often on our living conditions as well. Human beings have not yet, within a mere few decades, become androids with spe- cially conditioned mega-brains, and heaven send they never do! The only mutations to have taken place are in our lifestyles. Such mutations are recurrent, bringing about what Fernand Braudel has called nutritional revolutions and Pierre Gourou 1 ‘the deter- minism of civilization’. ‘Nutritional choices and the debate they imply are the result of processes lying very far back in the past’, Braudel has said. At a conference in Brussels as early as 1982, one of the outstanding European researchers of the time, Guy Fauconneau, made a brief statement: In our industrialized countries, the personal energy requirements of individuals have dropped considerably as a result of the drop in the amount of physical exercise taken (with the use of lifts, cars, etc.), while less energy is also lost in maintaining body tem- perature (in air-conditioned environments, etc.). The calorie requirements per day, over 3000 calories in 1950, are now only 2200 calories for men and 1800 calories for women. 2 We should be glad to see that the Western nations at least no longer have the dif- ficulty that still besets the developing countries in providing the number of calories necessary for the health of their populations. For the record, remember that at the end of the French Revolution the average figures for calorie consumption in France, for instance, were an intake of only about 2000 calories a day in the optimum conditions, with cereals (mainly the coarser cereals but also some choicer varieties) making up over 60 per cent of that amount in the form of bread and porridge, and account- ing for 17 per cent of the household budget after expenditure on meat and wine. In the industrialized countries, dietary habits have changed progressively since the early nineteenth century. But towards the end of the 1950s, once post-war condi- tions were well established, the pace of change speeded up. In particular, there was a very marked drop in the consumption of the cereals used for bread making, as well as the consumption of potatoes and all leguminous plants, to which the poor had resorted in the past. The watchword seems to be: a slim figure is all-important. On the other hand, thanks to those magazines that are constantly writing about dietary principles, the consumption of dairy products providing plenty of calcium seems to remain stable. We may now drink less milk, but we have taken to dairy desserts, ice creams and cheeses, all well promoted by the advertising industry. On the other hand, and this was the most notable phenomenon of the end of the twen- tieth century, consumption of animal products (in the past the good, fortifying diet of the upper classes and well-off ) grew by 50 per cent between 1955 and 1978, increasing by an average extra kilo to a kilo and a half of an individual’s consump- tion of such products per year). We have grown richer. A few years later some of the wealthiest countries, such as the United States, New Zealand, Australia and France, were consuming almost three-quarters of their protein in the form of animal protein, usually of bovine origin. The movement seems to be irreversible. How has this come about? All the industrialized countries initially satisfied their quantitative requirements of total proteins with about 90 grams a day; then the avail- ability of proteins increased, and those of vegetable origin were progressively replaced 691 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 691

S cience and C onscience in the D iet by animal proteins consisting mainly of meat – beef, mutton and lamb, pork prod- ucts and poultry – and secondly of eggs and dairy produce. This development is also evident in the increase in lipids (fatty acids) available, especially in France, Belgium and Germany. Lipids are often associated with animal proteins, fat meat such as pork and charcuterie, and dairy products (milk and cheese). But here, and in parallel, we also see the beginning of the struggle against cholesterol, which has been a pre- occupation of medicine and the media ever since. A detailed examination of the different sources of protein in various industrialized countries will show several stages of development in their consumption. Some coun- tries (Italy, Spain, Portugal, Japan) still consume 45–50 grams a day of vegetable protein, partly in the form of cereals (pasta and rice in Italy and Portugal) or legumes (peas, beans, soya in China, Spain and Japan). The ‘most advanced’ countries, by way of contrast, eat hardly any vegetable proteins: 25 grams a day in Sweden, 28 grams in Germany, 30 grams in the United States and Switzerland. This is not enough. Ideally, eggs can provide at least up to 5 grams of animal protein a day. In the United States, where people were eating 5.5 grams of egg a day before the Second World War, consumption has fallen to 4.8 grams. This may be a sign of increasing prosperity among the working classes, allowing more lavish menus. In industrialized countries with temperate climates, dairy products provide a large quantity of the animal proteins consumed: Sweden traditionally eats the most (38 grams a day), followed by Switzerland (30 grams) and then by the United States, France and Great Britain. The Mediterranean countries, not traditionally great con- sumers of dairy foods, have increased their consumption in the early twenty-first century: the people of Italy and Spain now eat an average 20 grams a day. Portugal still consumes only 10 grams and Japan barely 8 grams of dairy produce a day per inhabitant. But this is only a matter of cultural customs. Finally, fish provides a considerable amount of animal protein: the average per day and per inhabitant is over 18 grams a day in Japan, 15 grams in Portugal, 13 grams in Spain and about 9 grams in Sweden. Because of the problems that have arisen in the fishing industry, not just offshore but also deep-sea fishing, and the situation of fish stocks, which are now in danger of being over-exploited, it is becoming more and more difficult for the fish-eating peoples to maintain this level of consumption, and we are inexorably moving towards an increase in fish farming. This subject has been covered in the chapter on the history of fish. To return to meat, its average total consumption per day per inhabitant is now 41 grams in the United States, 38 in France, 32 in Germany, 28 in Switzerland, 25 in Great Britain, 24 in Italy, 22 in Sweden and 21 in Spain, but only 17 grams per day per inhabitant in Portugal and 10.5 grams in Japan. In contrast are the poorest countries of Asia, where some one and a half billion people eat on average only 3 kilos of meat a year, while in Africa (with about 813 million stomachs to fill) each person eats an average 10 kilos of meat a year, includ- ing hunted game. However, the billion plus people of China have reached the level of some 20 kilos of meat per person a year, thanks to enormous efforts made over the last few years. We must not forget traditional insect-eating customs, very common among the poorer rural inhabitants of black Africa and South-East Asia, who can find valuable 692 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 692

AR eassuring F uture proteins otherwise missing from their diet in the form of fat termites, ants, scorpions, crickets or juicy spiders collected in the bush. In Chinese cities the consumption of such small creatures, specially raised and eaten fried, has become fashionable. They are regarded as delicacies, but do not feature in the statistics. For some time now, an increase in meat consumption by over a kilo and a half per year per inhabitant has been the general rule in almost all the industrialized coun- tries. In the United States this rise in meat consumption began before the Second World War. It was seen in France and some of the EEC countries (the future European Union) from 1950 onwards. Finally, Japan, Portugal and Spain entered the race only after 1960, like most of the East European countries which were still behind the Iron Curtain, and some rich countries with different dietary habits: Switzerland with its dairy produce in 1963; Sweden and Denmark, traditionally fishing countries, in 1972. At present little more than a quarter of the human race is taking part in this race to eat more meat, with the exception since 1963 of Great Britain. Is that a case of a change in national taste? No studies have been made of this phenomenon, unusual as it is, even though it might serve as a good example. 3 France heads the European Union, with average consumption per person being 87 kilos a year of butcher’s meat, consisting of 26 kilos of beef, 35 kilos of pork, 13.5 kilos of poultry and 13 kilos of other meat. In the Eastern countries, the new accession countries to the EU, the rise in beef consumption has been almost 25 kilos in some fifteen years, a sign of a general rise in the standard of living. It is clear that the French have maintained this level of increase in meat consumption by a kilo and a half per year per person, and a large part of the extra meat eaten, in the past mainly provided by poultry and pork as in other European countries, began to consist of beef. France is one of the only countries of the world in this situation, along with the United States (with 127.5 kilos eaten per inhabitant per year), show- ing both the wealth of France and the traditional desire of the French to eat well. In addition, the world rise in the consumption of pork and poultry has been made possible by special livestock rearing, using animal feed adapted to particular breeds that have been progressively improved by geneticists. We shall return to this subject a little later. At present a quarter of the human race thus accounts for two-thirds of the rise in consumption of butcher’s meat. The industrialized countries consume 90 million metric tons of meat out of a total of 138 million tons eaten, that is to say 65 per cent of world consumption; the rise is above 2.3 million tons per year out of a total of 3.5 million tons in the first years of this century. In the second decade of the twenty-first century, now quite close, we may expect to see a huge rise of over 2 million tons of meat eaten in an increasingly capitalist and Westernized China. For the rest of the world it will probably be a figure in the order of 3 million tons in view of demographic increases and the industrialization of a certain number of countries, coming to a total of around 5 million extra tons of meat a year to be provided. Meanwhile, dairy production in the industrialized countries of Eastern and Western Europe continues to grow as a result of the increased productivity of dairy cows, which seem to be aiming to break record after record. Milk production amounts to 100 million tons, say 2 or 3 per cent extra each year, and if effective regulations 693 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 693

The export of milk powder to the developing countries may seem too easy a solution, but it is much to be hoped that if and when peace returns to most of the world (watch this space!) it will be possible to distribute milk in that form. Still in connection with the dairy industry, if the development of traditional dairy production in tropical countries remains unpredictable because those climates do not favour the keeping of dairy cows with a high milk yield, the breeding of buffalo cows, each producing 1,000 litres of milk with a 7 per cent fat content per year, could provide milk suitable for infant feeding in the now developing tropical countries, and the same applies to goats. While the production of animal foods as a whole is rising regularly to satisfy demand in all the industrialized countries with highly developed systems of agriculture and stock- rearing, aquaculture is not yet well organized, and considerable efforts in that area are called for. Aquaculture and aviculture are economic models that can be exported by industrialized countries to developing countries with populations justifiably wish- ing to increase their consumption of animal proteins. At present, over three-quarters of proteins consumed in the developed countries are of animal origin, as against 20 per cent in the past. While that means that grain for bread making no longer plays the leading part, many problems arise and gener- ate other problems. If more meat is to be produced, then what will be the fate of cereals, the traditional mainspring of many economies? The reply is unequivocal: in future one of the first duties of agriculture will be to produce animal feed, using those cereals that are best adapted to the purpose. Agriculture and stock-breeding must adapt to the change in nutritional fashions, and indeed to the mutation of society as a whole. We can no longer expect to find passive resources which can be exploited at will. We must not, we cannot go on producing anything we like if no need for it is felt, and doing so at the expense of what will prove to be necessary. Wastage in the name of tradition can no longer be tolerated. On the other hand, the production of food for human consumption must obey criteria of quality rather than quantity. That holds good for wine, for wheat, for fruits and milk. In future there will be great competition to provide the best quality at the best price. A price guaranteed to farmers ought to cover everything that exactly cor- responds to our needs. Just as states plan ahead with a financial budget, it is becoming increasingly necessary to plan a budget of nutritional resources. The idea of a ‘planned economy’ may not sound attractive, but only a system of regulation will enable us to solve the problems of shortages, or of the equally demoralizing waste of excess stocks. In future we may have to make high-risk monocultures and mono-stock breed- ing obsolete. Like industrialists, farmers are affected by the profound changes and new needs in our society. Agricultural raw materials, of great diversity and extremely sensitive to pedological conditions (affecting the soil and the climate), must have their composition better defined, and phytotechnology (plant engineering) must be used to regularize that composition. Those raw materials will still have to be classified according to their composition and the uses for which they are intended (for instance wheat for bread or wheat for animal feed). 694 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 694

AR eassuring F uture Animal foods such as pork and chicken and eggs and milk have been developed in the industrialized countries thanks to the great progress made by geneticists in perfecting more productive breeds, more particularly thanks to better energy yields (an indication of consumption) and a better nitrogenous output (the transformation of vegetable protein into animal protein for human consumption). 4 Research work in all institutes of agronomic research aims not solely to improve agricultural production but also to economize on energy and raw materials, as well as guaranteeing farmers’ incomes. The industrial rearing of pigs and poultry con- sumes large amounts of these vegetable proteins (cereals and oilcake). Among the best foodstuffs is soya, imported first from the United States, then from South America. In 1973 a price explosion and the American embargo called the bluff of the European powers. Only derisory quantities of home-grown oilseed rape were being produced in Western Europe, a mere 5 to 6 per cent of the quan- tity required. In 1977 work began to develop oil-yielding plants, including a new variety of oilseed rape (it contained no erucic acid and could thus also be used for cooking oil), sunflower, soya in the south-west of France, and plants with seeds con- taining oily proteins such as peas and field beans. Around 1995, much research was done on the potential of the lupin; there were even conferences on the plant. That may seem surprising: the lupin was highly prized by the ancient Egyptians and Romans, but why, one may ask, do research into this particular kind of large pea, specimens of which have been found in the foundations of pyramids? The fact is, however, that the seeds of this ornamental plant of the Papilionacae family are full of unjustly neglected or even unsuspected qualities. The lupin, being very high in useful proteins, can produce both an economical edible oil and cheap animal fodder. Growing it recovers nitrogen from the air, which it recycles in the soil, thus limiting the need to add fertilizer to subsequent crops. Its worldwide production in 2005 was no more than 1,365 thousand tons, but after being an excellent vegetable in classical antiquity it is certainly an oil plant for the future. Two examples of the interest taken in animal feed are particularly striking because they come from countries undergoing profound change: Brazil and Japan. Brazil had its sights set on a large animal-feed industry (8 million tons in 1976, 13.5 million tons in 1979), based mainly on maize (6.8 million tons) and soya oilcake (almost 2 million tons). This allowed the rapid rise of special stock-rearing programmes, particularly of poultry; at present Brazil is the second largest exporter of poultry, after the United States and ahead of France, concentrating on the Middle Eastern countries. Stock-rearing in Japan developed greatly from 1960 onwards, producing first eggs, then pork and poultry. Specialized stock-rearing programmes consumed growing quant- ities of animal feed: 2 million tons in 1960, 11 million in 1968, 20 million in 1979. The use of cereals for animal feed, imported mainly from Australia at the time, had passed from one million to 20 million tons ten years later. Meanwhile the Japanese stepped up their production of a variety of fish-meals for animal feed, consumption of which has reached a million tons, all of it produced locally, at the beginning of the present century. Ultimately the total amount of animal feed consumed by livestock is in the region of 800 million tons, nearly 100 million tons consisting of cereals or their derivatives. 695 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 695

S cience and C onscience in the D iet At present, on average, animal feed uses large amounts of the coarser cereals and oil-cake, but still contains 60 to 70 per cent of higher-quality produce which could potentially be used as food for human beings in the developing countries. Scientific researches, aware of the enormity of this scandalous situation, in itself one of the factors causing trouble in many parts of the world and capable of setting off a chain reaction, 5 are trying to develop not just foodstuffs exclusively for animal consumption as soon as possible, but also ways of rehabilitating high-quality prod- ucts for human consumption in an economical and pleasant-tasting form. All the same, we have to slow down the ‘race for meat’ before it reaches a level that endangers both human health and the balance of trade: a subject that has been covered in the chapter on meat. We have looked at the psychological factors involved in dietary choice, and they are as valid today as yesterday. The reasons deserve to be better analysed with a view to the wide distribution of meat substitutes that are sufficiently attractive, for instance purified and ‘texturized’ vegetable proteins, but do not resemble the ersatz products of the Second World War that left such bad memories behind. Another question is how to introduce these new products into everyday life, perhaps by adapt- ing them to the sociological customs of different populations. There could be good times ahead for sales and marketing departments, which are usually more successful than dire warnings issued by doctors. Our human ability to adapt is of course great, as the history of food over the ages has clearly shown. Here, however, we would need to understand the effect of the intake of different proteins on the physiology of various organs: the speed at which cellular structures are replaced, and the long-term results of ingesting the new products. In any case, it is best to eat vegetable proteins and fibres in the pleasant and nat- ural form of fruit and vegetables, and researches in the early years of the present century show that if biotechnological laboratories have so far been more interested in modifying animal cells, in future they will turn their attention to the vegetable kingdom. For a good twenty years now several American companies have invested sums we can only guess at in this subject. It would take several books, however, to cover the entire question of genetically modified organisms, those famous (or notorious) GM foods that have also become political issues. One of their prime objectives, say the supporters of GM foods, is to increase yields by improving the ability of crops to absorb all the nitrogen in fertilizers (part of which is not normally used, causing wastage), to extend cultivable areas of land by creating varieties or hybrid species resistant to drought, frost, wind and salt; to increase resistance to disease, pests and parasites. A dream, say some enthusiastically. A night- mare, others gloomily predict. Today, now that their quantitative needs are satisfied, the people of the industri- alized countries have increasingly pronounced qualitative tastes, not to say require- ments. Such tastes were once the prerogative of an elite, but subsequently spread as a result of sociological change, the ethnic mingling of populations, and better communications. But above all, the consumer’s criteria for choice now include practicality, and it is at this target that food scientists and industrialists now primarily aim. AR eassuring F uture products allowing food to be quickly prepared (even in ten minutes) have existed for some time, but are now more and more widely available: frozen chips, potato flakes for mashed potato, pre-cooked rice, pre-cooked semolina, even pre-cooked vegetables ready for use, and so forth. It is a fact that the time devoted to the preparation of family meals has decreased considerably within three generations because of the increasing numbers of women working outside the home. In 1930 the housewife spent three or four hours a day cooking. Today her granddaughter has no more than half an hour for cooking every weekday, that is to say quarter of an hour at the most for each meal if lunch is eaten at home. We must therefore expect to see even greater expansion in future of the range of quick-cook and ready-to-cook products, or those requiring only brief cooking, 6 such as fresh, canned or frozen ready meals, ready-prepared meat and chicken pieces. With domestic staff a thing of the past, even the festive meal for consumption at family reunions, weekends or social dinner parties now calls for greater ease of preparation. The question of time also applies to quick meals eaten at work, where a greatly reduced number of dishes is on offer, providing the requisite nutritional balance but requiring only non-specialized labour in self-service restaurants. This applies to both staff canteens and the corner cafés which, in much of Europe, have often accepted luncheon vouchers, as well as school canteens. Soon no one will be going home for lunch any more. Finally, the rhythm of the working day, the time spent getting to work, the increas- ing availability of leisure pursuits and second homes have given rise to a new habit all over Europe, one that had already existed for a long time in the United States and Canada: the big weekly shopping expedition to the supermarket on Saturday. In parallel we have the extension of the ‘cold chain’, with the common use of fam- ily freezers. The cold chain makes peeled and prepared products available, as well as ready meals and an increasingly large number of ice cream-based desserts, using up some of the surplus production of milk and fruits. But a warning note has been struck in Paris by Afssa, the Agence Française de sécurité sanitaire des aliments (French Agency for the Hygienic Safety of Foodstuffs): consumers are not always familiar with the imperatives of hygiene to be observed when, for instance, keeping fish in domestic fridges, which are often kept at the wrong temperature. ‘The flesh of fish, which contains more water than meat, encourages the proliferation of the micro-organisms that cause decay. Between 0° and 10°, the speed of deterioration in fish is multiplied by four’, explains Pierre Malle, head of the Agency’s fish products laboratory. The public needs to develop a whole new nutritional culture. The last item in the family meals of this future that has already begun are the ‘petits pots’ – small containers of complete meals for babies – and nutritionally bal- anced breakfast foods like muesli, based on cereals and dried fruits, which have spread to the four corners of the world. All these convenience products, easy and quick to use, are made by industries that can offer the requisite guarantees of hygiene and good nutrition. With their daily diet thus guaranteed, reassured consumers do not forget the qual- ity of life. Food of high quality eaten for pleasure in a convivial setting remains, in 697 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 697

There is no reason to expect any change there in the foreseeable future, particu- larly because a display of gastronomic competence is one of the signs of a general improvement in living standards. And let it be whispered in passing: it is all part of marketing strategy. Trade and advertising have fewer and fewer opportunities to revive fantasies of an age that was golden only for a select few. Above all, there is an enlight- ened amateur dormant in every one of us, and if select or prestige products are going to keep their share of the market, it is more important than ever for them to retain their quality and authenticity. Where meat is concerned, the prime quality parts of the animal are those served on special occasions, coming from beasts reared in a way that claims to combine natural methods with scrupulous hygiene. Veal and poultry must boast labels denot- ing something other than sales talk. The traditional appellation d’origine contrôlée for wine and cheese, showing that they come from the right region or are the right vintage, will remain the weapon of producers hoping to play the trump card of some- thing really exceptional to sell. The nomenklatura will always be with us. To retain a suggestion of hedonism, these products intended for pleasure con- sumption are now made according to traditional but improved processes, but still have the limited availability which is part of their charm. Only what is real is desir- able, tomorrow as it was yesterday. Thus wines are the subject of constant study by growers always on the lookout for improvement, for instance in Germany, where they have created vintages with an entirely new aroma, neither dry nor with a Muscat flavour, the offspring of new grape varieties bred with an eye to their genetics. Or there are American, Spanish or South African wines perfectly matured but with an alcohol level kept at 3 to 5 degrees. There is also talk of a wine that will be authentic but guaranteed to be alcohol-free! The expanding consumption of fresh vegetables and fruit from either the local countryside or the most distant parts of the planet, with standards becoming ever more demanding, calls for a transport industry worthy of the name, receiving supplies of crops picked at the right stage of maturity from anywhere at all to be driven, after sterilization, straight to the domestic refrigerator. We can see it happening today. Fruit and vegetables are living organs, and the ‘softer’ technologies, such as pre- refrigeration, barohydrometric treatments and ripening under carbon dioxide, con- trolled ionizing radiation (gamma rays and accelerated electrons) with very slight radioactivity to destroy micro-organisms, etc., used before items are packaged in film, allows vegetable products to stay fresh for a much longer period, so that from 2008 onwards they will appear, even after several months, to have been picked just that morning. Meat is already beginning to benefit from these ‘soft’ technologies. The long-term conservation of fish, an even more delicate food, was partly solved around 1983 by an American researcher and businessman who managed to retain all the hygienic and organoleptic qualities of ‘ultra-fresh’ fish for weeks without freezing in the finest, most sought-after fish products (which are also the most profitable), using a technique inspired by the Japanese working on the fishing grounds. Large species such as tuna and swordfish are bled and then immediately 698 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 698

AR eassuring F uture plunged into super-salt seawater at 1° C. This importer was thus able to produce a catalogue offering fish taken at sea off New York as rich in vitamins, despite the time it takes for it to be air-freighted to Japan for consumption raw in sushi, without waste and without the risk of decay. The earth is getting to be a very small place. We are increasingly coming to forget that in traditional civilizations ancestral dietary customs, religious prescriptions and the high price of good quality foods all imposed diets implying global shortages rather than the risk of excess. But now – and we should be ashamed to say so while a single baby is dying of starvation at the other end of the world – our Western society will soon be in danger of stifling the well- to-do under the great quantities of food they have available. With progress, the rise in living standards, and religious liberty, gluttony risks becoming a scourge in its own turn. For some years now disorders caused by excess have proliferated in the industri- alized countries, led by the United States as the proponents of ‘super-size’ every- thing: obesity (16 per cent of French children are overweight, diabetes (2 million French adults have Type 2 obesity-related diabetes), cardiovascular disorders (with 17,000 French people dying per year), and cerebrovascular accidents (strokes). In March 2003, at the request of the World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), an international team of experts produced a report which made the headlines with some particularly strik- ing recommendations on food and physical exercise. Its aim was to help govern- ments tackle these chronic illnesses, which are becoming more of a threat every year. All over the world, the burden of these diseases is rapidly growing. In 2001, says the report, they were responsible for about 59 per cent of 56.9 million deaths reg- istered throughout the world, and 46 per cent of worldwide morbidity. ‘This report is of great importance, since it contains the optimum scientific data we have at present on the link between diet, nutrition, physical exercise and chronic illness. It gives the collective opinion of a group of experts with an international repu- tation on a problem of world-wide significance’, says the man who presided over that group, Dr Ricardo Uauy, head of the Institute of Nutritional and Dietary Technology of the University of Chile, and Professor of Public Health Nutrition at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. The report advises on ways of maintaining a good balance in daily food intake and on expending more energy: we should • eat less high-calorie food rich in saturated fatty acids and sugar; • reduce our salt intake; • eat more fresh fruit and vegetables; • take at least an hour of moderate exercise every day. Based on analysis of the best data at present available, and on the opinion of 30 experts, the report insists that daily calorie intake must be in proportion to the energy expended. Since studies show that eating too much high-calorie food leads to weight gain, the report recommends limiting the intake of saturated fatty acids, sugars and salt, and points out that these substances are present to excess in snacks and processed 699 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 699

S cience and C onscience in the D iet foods and drinks. The quality of fats and oils used and the quantity of salt absorbed, says the report, can also have an influence on cardiovascular illnesses such as strokes and heart attacks. The report appeared when the WHO was drawing up a world strategy for nutri- tion, physical exercise and health, in line with a resolution passed by the member states of the organization in May 2002. It was officially published in April 2003 in the form of a technical report by the WHO and the FAO, accompanied by an evaluation by those organizations, with examples of steps that should be taken to put the recommendations into practice. It made a great scientific contribution to drawing up a worldwide strategy aiming to slow down the progress of cardiovascular illnesses, several forms of cancer, diabetes, obesity, osteoporosis and dental disease. The FAO is now helping the OMS to perfect this strategy. In following up the conclusions of the report, it will set about deciding what information to gather, observ- ing nutritional methods, and anticipating the consequences of the report’s recom- mendations on all links in the food chain and on agricultural and trade policies. National and regional organs will also be able to refer to the report in order to give local communities precise directives on nutrition and physical exercise. ‘The report’, Dr Uauy explains, ‘indicates what elements the diet should contain, and the amount of physical exercise desirable to maintain good health and protect against the principal chronic disorders linked to nutrition: coronary disease and hyper- tension, cancer, diabetes, obesity, osteoporotic fractures and dental disease.’ In fact a great many deaths attributed to chronic illness originate in risk factors that could be easily avoided, such as: • hypertension or high blood pressure; • hypercholesterolaemia, the metabolic disorder due to high blood cholesterol; • obesity; • lack of physical exercise. More and more people in the developing world now suffer from chronic illness, while only a few decades ago such disorders were associated only with the wealthier countries. According to the report, urbanization as a consequence of the general exodus from the rural environment plays an important part in this upheaval. Town dwellers usually eat more high-calorie food rich in saturated fatty acids and refined sugars. The sudden change of diet, together with a sedentary way of life, has devastating effects on the health of the poorer inhabitants of modern towns and cities. ‘Fats and carbohydrates are not all the same; it is useful to distinguish between them’, Dr Uuay points out. ‘We need to eat less high-calorie food, in particular less food rich in saturated fatty acids and sugar, we should take exercise, choose non- saturated rather than saturated fats, eat less salt, eat plenty of fruit, vegetables and leguminous plants, and give priority in our diet to food of vegetable origin and fish.’ A diet rich in fruit and vegetables – at least 400 grams a day – containing micro- nutrients to stimulate the immune system can thus strengthen our natural defences against infectious illness. 700 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 700

AR eassuring F uture In particular, it is recommended that fats eaten do not exceed 15–30 per cent of daily high-calorie intake, and that saturated fatty acids represent less than 10 per cent of that total. Still according to the report, carbohydrates should provide the main part of our energy needs, say 55–75 per cent of daily intake, and free sugars should be kept to less than 10 per cent. Proteins should make up 10–15 per cent of our daily ration of calories, and the amount of salt taken should be below 5 grams a day. The trouble is that limiting salt consumption is almost impossible. Just as organ- isms need magnesium and potassium they also, of course, need salt. And salt in the natural state is also found in almost all foods. ‘If we ate only natural, non-processed foods, our consumption of salt would be one gram a day, sufficient for our physio- logical requirements. But we are now consuming on average ten grams a day’, points out Pierre Menneton, a French researcher at the National Institute of Health and Medical Research,. And since many people automatically add salt to the food on their plate, after it has already been salted during cooking, that means 20 grams or more taken every day. Try calculating what that comes to in a life of 75 years or more! Not to mention all the salt we ingest without knowing it in products con- cocted by the food industry, for instance nibbles served with drinks. The consequences to our health of all this excess salt are well known: for instance, as yet another WHO report entitled ‘Reducing salt intake in populations’ reminds us: increased arterial pressure in those suffering from cardiovascular and renal dis- ease, loss of calcium (leading to osteoporosis) and magnesium, stomach cancer, a higher frequency of asthmatic attacks. So we know that excess salt leads straight to a public health problem unknown to our ancestors, and it can certainly be counted among the diseases of civilization. It is now 40 years since scientists and doctors all over the world began sounding the alarm. Only five years ago the various health authorities seriously took note of it, while the agricultural and nutritional industries still turn a deaf ear, or adopt a pose of offended dignity. But why? And will legal measures have to be taken? It can be said at once that general apathy is the first response to any proposed change in our habits. Secondly, salt is an ordinary condiment with a taste that masks the flavour of foods of only moderately good quality – or even, sad to say, of mediocre or poor quality. Furthermore, in meat products such as ground meat, ham, and chicken fillets, salt represents an economy because the more of it is present the more water the foods in question will contain. And they are sold by weight. Another factor is that some such foods may be left until after their eat-by date before they are con- sumed, and salt, relatively speaking, helps to prevent decomposition. Then again, salt added to foods (up to 80 per cent too much in certain specialities known all over the world) leads consumers to drink more: wine, apéritifs, cocktails, soft drinks. Multiply the figures by dozens or even hundreds of millions of consumers, and you have dozens and dozens of billions of euros, pounds, dollars, roubles or yen going into the food and drink industry, not to mention the taxes imposed by the various states. In July 2007 the European Commission promulgated a system of nutritional labelling. Other authorities will follow – but only 12 per cent of consumers in Western Europe take any notice. 701 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 701

S cience and C onscience in the D iet In addition, physical exercise accounts for much of the energy expended every day, and is thus necessary for calorific balance and weight. The report recommends an hour a day of moderate physical exercise such as walking on most days of the week to maintain a normal physical weight, especially for people who spend most of their time sitting down. The WHO and FAO hope that the conclusions of the report will provide the mem- ber states with conclusive facts on which to base an international health strategy. It invites governments to give simple, realistic and concrete directives concerning diet, and cites the examples of Finland and Japan, countries which have taken ener- getic measures to bring about change in the habits and nutritional behaviour of their populations. As a result, risk factors have clearly diminished and the frequency of chronic illness has fallen in those countries. If we are to reduce the rate of death and disability caused by chronic illness, says the report, we must be aware that these pathological conditions can be avoided, we must attack the problem seriously and create an environment that promotes good health. That will mean establishing working relationships between communities and the public authorities, supporting local initiatives in schools and the workplace, and inducing the food industry to participate. The new champions in this battle against the dangers threatening civilization are to be found in laboratories. There is no disputing with their principal weapon, which is to decrease consumption of simple sugars in favour of polymerized carbohydrates obtained by the hydrolysis of maize starch or vegetable fibres by means of an enzyme. The simple sugar that passes unnoticed because a good half of it is concealed in soft drinks, ice cream and biscuits is responsible for extra consumption in France, to take that country alone, rising from 10 kilos a year per person in the post-war period to 40 kilos in 2007, i.e., over 100 grams a day (450 kilocalories). And we are still far from the United States, where the population consumes on average 60 kilos a year. We must thus replace this concealed sugar by sweeteners containing many fewer calories. The market, fortunately, is beginning to drop the habit of offering consumers over-sugared products like milky desserts and fruit drinks that educate children’s tastes poorly. Manufacturers also seize their chance to flood the market with new products. We have to be wilier than they are and know how to interpret the informa- tion given on the labels. For some time it has been possible to replace sugar by saccharine derived from toluene, a hydrocarbon. Next came the cyclamates, the product of a carbon chain existing in the molecules of certain organic compounds. But their safety has been chal- lenged, and it is claimed that they may predispose those who take them to cancer. Be that as it may, aspartame, a dipeptide made up of two amino acids (aspartic acid and methylated phenylalanine) and produced by fermentation with micro-organisms on the old leavening principle, has 200 times the sweetening power of sugar. Another sweetener, thaumatin, is a protein containing 206 amino acids instead of two, and is extracted from a tropical plant. At present, particularly in the United States where a great deal of work is being done on enzymes, the first years of the present century saw research into an amy- lase that can be used at 80° C in an acid environment, and can save several million 702 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 702

AR eassuring F uture dollars a year on the cost of making sugar from maize starch . . . not to mention the savings in terms of public health. Fructose (which has 130 –150 per cent of the sweet- ening power of saccharose), made from maize glucose by means of enzymes fixed with resin, is already in common use in the United States, particularly in drinks. It has 30 –50 per cent fewer calories than saccharose. Maize farmers would seem to have good times ahead. But what will become of those tropical countries that live by growing sugar cane and are already severely affected by beet sugar? The solution may lie in using cane sugar to make fuel for cars, but that is another story. Fats are another problem. Leaving aside the great classic cheeses with their famous names and regional production, which may be considered foods for special occa- sions, the future for daily consumption lies in low-fat cheese, which can still achieve high gastronomic quality, for instance nine-month-old Italian Parmesan, containing only 33 per cent fat matter. Eating lower-fat foods need not be a deprivation. In the present century cheese makers often employ a procedure which was still revolutionary around the 1980s: membrane processing. It is rather a pity that no more attractive term was devised for this system of molecular filtration, which enables cheese makers to separate small from large molecules and thus to separate the three components of milk: fat matter, proteins and lactose (sugar). The mineral membranes used, acting as filters, were first developed for the nuclear industry. They allow cheese makers to adjust the amount of fat matter in their products, enrich or otherwise the protein level, and eliminate extra lactose, which is often difficult for diabetics to tolerate, giving it to young calves. A high-protein skimmed milk, invented by the French in 1984, has now become the ideal in modern dietetics. The development of membrane technology and knowledge about the coagula- tion of milk proteins by pressure in cheese making on the one hand, and the role of the lactic bacteria in acidifying them on the other, had already made it possible to manufacture cheese from a pre-cheese liquid of the same composition as cheese itself, which could then have rennet and cultures added. This procedure makes it unnecessary to strain out lactoserum, and allows lactoproteins of high nutritional quality that are wasted in traditional cheese-making to be recovered. The result is to increase yield by 15 per cent for the same quantity of milk as before, while improving the nutritional quality of the product but without affecting the organoleptic quality of the cheese. It also means a 70 per cent saving on rennet. The procedure was developed for fromages frais and feta, and work is still being done on extending it to soft cheeses such as Camembert. Recovered fermentations have restored the almost forgotten flavour of the past to industrially made cheese. A drop in consumption of fats and the modification of their composition to increase the amount of unsaturated lipids has thus led to the creation of products which, when we calculate the proportion they occupy in the daily diet, we know do not amount to more than 30 per cent of total calories ingested. At some point in the third millennium, cholesterol will come to seem as outdated as scrofula or the plague. Even lower-fat ‘charcuterie’ is now being produced by using poultry and fish to make products inspired by the classic specialities of gastronomy. The agents here are binders based on polyosides (vegetable ‘fibres’) and proteins with only a modest amount of fat matter. Following on from the idea of defatted fat, we have low-fat ‘butter’ based on a lactoserum with gelling agents derived from seaweed. We can also enjoy 703 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 703

S cience and C onscience in the D iet ‘skimmed’ cream containing gelling agents, and keep traditional cream for special occasions. More and more low-fat food is being eaten, and thinking about dietetics is becoming second nature. The years 2000 onwards will be healthily lean years, and our arteries will no longer age – or hardly at all! As well as skimmed cream, bread is available that has been made lighter through breaking up the starch molecules by extrusion during baking, a particularly efficacious process that allows a change in the molecules of products such as biscuit dough containing less than 30 per cent water. Since the process saves on energy, it is even more beneficial than the use of enzymes, which work only in an aqueous environment, meaning that water has to be evapo- rated from a substance after treatment. The food industry can now make chemically modified starches by means of pre- gelatization, giving excellent results in the making of savoury or sweet patisserie which must undergo the cycle of freezing and defrosting. Classic dough products do not lend themselves to the cycle so well. The new formula allows us to predict improve- ments in ready meals that need only be heated up or cooked in the microwave before serving, but still contain a good nutritional balance, such as pizzas, quiches and filled croissants. For we cannot do without a certain amount of bread, in whatever form we eat it. However, decreasing our present excess consumption of meat remains one of the main objectives of nutritional research. Whether it is done for reasons of the eco- nomy, public health or the health of agriculture itself, animal production must no longer take precedence over plant production, wasting poorly used resources. To recover an economic, agricultural and nutritional balance we must stop wasting the proteins of vegetable origin mentioned above, and use them attractively in foods. A certain number of studies are being done on those polyamides that are hard to digest, better known simply as ‘fibres’ (the bran of cereals, the pods of leguminous plants, the leaves and stems of vegetables). It would be good to know more about their exact functions. The alimentary bolus provides a slowly absorbed food that is necessary to the intestinal flora, and the traditional food of underdeveloped coun- tries, which is rich in cellulose (often, unfortunately, an appetite suppressant) has been linked to a lower rate of cancers of the digestive passages. It would be better to find a pleasurable way of consuming high-fibre meals than to buy expensive and not very tasty bran biscuits or take constant medicaments. Introducing technology from other fields into the food industry may ultimately be the elixir of youth needed by agriculture and consumers alike. The food industries, taking new requirements into account, must not only make products that relate to consumers’ real needs, but if the cost is to be lower, and the wastage at intermediate stages reduced, must make them in a better formulated but also simpler way. Here they will need to take advantage of the discoveries constantly being made in biotechnology, applying them both to the sector of micro-organisms and animal cells (fish and meat) and vegetables (cereals, seaweed, fruits and veget- ables), and make use of technology adopted from the realms of chemical, physical and mechanical engineering. Such technologies, which may seem a long way removed from our diet, derive from studies of the mechanism of fluids, enzymatic catalysis, but have immediate 704 9781405181198_4_027.qxd 14/08/2008 10:34 AM Page 704

AR eassuring F uture applications, for instance in the membrane processing just mentioned. And let us not forget the progress made in asepsis and automatic functioning which have such an influence on the development of methods of food conservation. Hitherto confined to work on sugar refining and oil milling, the food-processing industries that are developing new ways of treating starches and glucoses could expand dramatically into the field of vegetable proteins. Raw materials or intermediate food products are already being prepared with characteristics similar to those of alloys in the steel industry. Furthermore, knowledge of the physico-chemical characteristics of molecules in the food-processing industry will allow the progressive replacement of additives (a technological makeshift) by compounds derived from the breaking down of agri- cultural raw materials to make the best possible use of such functional qualities as their ability to emulsify, act as gelling agents or expand substances. Proteins will pro- gressively replace caragenates, alginates and so on. Will all these scientific guarantees lead to a ‘planned’ diet? Certainly not in the immediate future, and that future may last at least a generation. We will always have the choice between the two alternatives: convenience food for every day, tradition- ally prepared food for special and convivial occasions. We are none the less moving towards more uniform nutrition in the longer or shorter term. Dairy products such as yoghurt are already being eaten in the Mediterranean countries and Africa, where they were unknown in the middle of the last century, were found only in pharmacies after the Second World War, but at pre- sent are widely available in supermarkets – and supermarkets themselves are also widespread. However, although we might fear that foods will be standardized, the effect will be diluted by the development of a variety of products increasingly designed to tempt the consumer. But the consumer, so it already appears, is no longer determined to eat unwisely. Nutritional information is now freely available, a phenomenon undoubtedly fostered by advertising and the media, but with some good effects. The schools of many coun- tries have finally realized that nutritional education is as important as civic educa- tion. Nutritional teaching is finding a place parallel to the modern teaching of biology. Such education is necessary from childhood if consumers are to make the best use of their capital in the form of health, on their own account and that of their families. The most encouraging example is that of the United States where, as the result of a massive and well-received press campaign, the rate of early death associated with heart disease has dropped by 20 per cent because of a drop in the consumption of salt and fats. Salted ‘herbs’ enabled the first American colonists to eat greens all through the winter.
